isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - SINGLE REDUCTION, SINGLE SPEED AXLES: SPICER D135-S, F155-S, F170-S SERIES - INSTALL - RING GEAR AND PINION TOOTH CONTACT PATTERN

svcproc.title: RING GEAR AND PINION TOOTH CONTACT PATTERN
svcproc.para: The toe of the gear tooth is the portion of the tooth surface at the end towards the center.
The heel of the gear tooth is the portion of the tooth surface at the outer end.
The top land of a gear tooth is the surface of the top of the tooth.

step1.para: Paint ring gear teeth with marking compound and rotate with pinion to obtain correct pattern ( Figure 66).

figure.caption: Figure 66. Marking Compound on Ring Gear Teeth

step1.para: The tooth contact patterns should have the same general shape and position as the ring gear teeth shown in Figure 67.

If the pattern is concentrated more toward the heel ( Figure 68), backlash must be reduced. Recheck backlash as described in INSTALL, DIFFERENTIAL. To reduce backlash, loosen the right side adjusting ring until the measured backlash is within specifica- tion. The tooth contact pattern should now have the same general shape and location as shown in Figure 67. If the contact pattern still does not conform, less backlash than normal is required. To avoid reducing differential bearing pre- load excessively, further loosening of the right hand adjusting ring should be accompanied by equal tightening of the left hand adjusting ring. Place a dial indicator directly on each adjusting ring to measure the exact amount of additional adjustment. Decreasing backlash moves the ring gear toward the pinion.

figure.caption: Figure 68. Ring Gear Out Too Far

step1.para: If the pattern is concentrated at the toe ( Figure 69), more backlash is required. Recheck backlash. To increase backlash, tighten the right side adjusting ring further until the measured backlash is within specification. The tooth contact pattern should now spread more across the ring gear tooth as in Figure 67. If the contact pattern still does not conform, more backlash than normal is required. To avoid increasing differential bearing preload excessively, further tightening of the right hand adjusting ring should be accompanied by equal loosening of the left hand adjusting ring. Place a dial indicator directly on each adjusting ring to measure the exact amount of additional adjustment. Increasing backlash moves the ring gear away from the pinion.

figure.caption: Figure 69. Ring Gear In Too Far

step1.para: If a pattern is concentrated at the ring gear tooth root ( Figure 70), the pinion is too close to the ring gear. It must be moved out and away to establish its proper mounting distance and contact pattern as shown in Figure 67. This is accomplished by choosing a thicker pinion bearing cage shim. Re-adjust pinion-to-ring gear backlash, as required, once proper pinion mounting distance has been established.

If pattern is concentrated at the tooth top land ( Figure 71), the pinion is too far away from the ring gear and must be moved closer to the ring gear to establish its proper mounting distance and tooth contact pattern. This is accomplished by selecting a thinner pinion bearing cage shim. Re-adjust pinion-to-ring gear backlash as required once proper pinion mounting distance has been established.

After proper ring gear pattern is achieved, again tighten the differential bearing cap bolts to 115 to 135 ft-lbs. (156 to 183 N•m). Install adjusting ring retainers and new cotter pins of proper size ( Figure 72).

figure.caption: Figure 72. Tighten Differential Bearing Cap Bolts
